revision.text:
'''Aesthetic distance''' refers to the gap between a viewer's conscious reality and the fictional reality presented in a work of art. When a reader becomes fully engrossed in the illusory narrative world of a book, the author has achieved a close aesthetic distance. If the author then jars the reader from the reality of the story, essentially reminding the reader they are reading a book, the author is said to have "violated the aesthetic distance." <ref>[http://academic.brooklyn.cuny.edu/english/melani/lit_term.html Literary terms]</ref><ref>[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/aesthetic+distance Merriam-Webster]</ref>
The concept originates from [[Immanuel_Kant|Immanuel Kant's]] [[Critique of Judgement]], where he establishes the notion of ''disinterested delight'' which does not depend on the subject's having a desire for the object itself, he writes, "delight in beautiful art does not, in the pure judgement of taste, involve an immediate interest. [...] it is not the object that is of immediate interest, but rather the inherent character of the beauty qualifying it for such a partnership-a character, therefore, that belongs to the very essence of beauty."<ref>Kant, Immanuel (1790). 'Critique of Pure Judgement.' trans. Meredith, James Creed. Blacksburg: Virginia Tech. 91.</ref>
The term aesthetic distance itself derives from an article by Edward Bullough published in 1912. In that article, he begins with the image of a passenger on a ship observing fog at sea. If the passenger thinks of the fog in terms of danger to the ship, the experience is not aesthetic, but to regard the beautiful scene in detached wonder is to take legitimate aesthetic attitude. One must feel, but not too much. Bullough writes, "Distance … is obtained by separating the object and its appeal from one's own self, by putting it out of gear with practical needs and ends. Thereby the 'contemplation' of the object becomes alone possible."<ref>Bullough, Edward (1912/1989). '"Psychical Distance" as a Factor in Art and as an Aesthetic Principle.' Dickie, G., Sclafani, R., Roblin, R. ''Aesthetics: A Critical Anthology.'' 2nd ed. New York: St. Martin's. 322.</ref>
Authors of film, fiction, drama, and poetry evoke different levels of aesthetic distance. For instance, [[William Faulkner]] tends to invoke a close aesthetic distance by using [[first-person narrative]] and [[Stream_of_consciousness_(narrative_mode)|stream of consciousness]], while [[Ernest Hemingway]] tends to invoke a greater aesthetic distance from the reader through use of [[Narrative_mode#Third-person_view|third person narrative]].
==Violating the aesthetic distance==
Anything that pulls a viewer out of the reality of a work of fiction is said to be a violation of aesthetic distance. An easy example in theater or film is "breaking the fourth wall," when characters suspend the progress of the story to speak directly to the audience. When the aesthetic distance is deliberately violated in theater, it is known as the [[distancing effect]], or ''Verfremdungseffekt'', a concept coined by playwright [[Bertolt Brecht]].
Many examples of violating the aesthetic distance may also be found in [[meta-fiction]]. [[William Goldman]], in ''[[The Princess Bride]]'', repeatedly interrupts his own fairy tale to speak directly to the reader. In the musical, ''[[Stop the World I Want to Get Off]]'', the [[protagonist]], ''Littlechap'', periodically stops the progress of the play to address the audience directly.
In film, the aesthetic distance is often violated unintentionally. Examples might include a director's cameo, poor special effects, or perhaps blatant [[product placement]] - any can be enough to pull a viewer out of the reality of the film. [[David Mamet]] in ''[[On Directing Film]]'' asserts that any direct depiction of graphic sex or violence in film is an inherent violation of aesthetic distance, as audience members will instinctively make judgments as to whether or not what they just saw was real, and thus be pulled out of the story-telling.
==See also==
*[[Distancing effect]] *[[Suspension of disbelief]] *[[Fourth wall]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox person |name=Ahmed Al Bahrani
أحمد البحراني |image= |image_size = |caption= |birth_name= |birth_date={{birth date|df=y|1965|7|21}} |birth_place= Tuarej, (near Baghdad), Iraq |death_date= |death_place= |occupation=Sculptor, artist |residence= Iraq, Jordan, Qatar, Sweden |nationality = Iraqi |education = Institute of Fine Arts (Baghdad) |years_active= }} '''Ahmed Al Bahrani''', ({{lang-ar|'''أحمد البحراني'''}}) (born 1965) is an [[Iraqi people|Iraqi]] sculptor. Ahmed Al Bahrani is one of the most famous Iraqi sculptors, now living in exile."Ahmed Al Bahrani," [Biographical Notes], Gary Nader Gallery, [http://garynader.com/artist-det.php?item=46 Online:] == Life == Ahmed Al Bahrani was born in 1965, in Tuarej on the Euphrates River, near Babylon.There is some confusion surrounding his place of birth. Some secondary sources, such as Bahrani, Z. and Shabout, N.M., ''Modernism and Iraq,'' Miriam and Ira D. Wallach Art Gallery and Columbia University, 2009, p. 92 state that he was born in Babylon, while other sources claim that he was born in Karbala; however in an interview, the sculptor explicitly stated that he was born in a small village, called Tuarej, near Babylon. See: "The Iraqi sculptor Ahmad Al-Bahrani told Asharq Al-Awsat: I am part of Qatari culture and am proud," [Interview - translated from Arabic], ''Al Sharq,'' 2 April, 2016, [https://www.al-sharq.com/news/details/412673] He recalls that as a child, he would withdraw from the games played by other boys, to model clay on the riverbank. He also recalls that on school trips, he was taken to see some of Iraq's ancient monuments and that his reaction to them was different to other boys."The Iraqi sculptor Ahmad Al-Bahrani told Asharq Al-Awsat: I am part of Qatari culture and am proud," [Interview - translated from Arabic], ''Al Sharq,'' 2 April, 2016, [https://www.al-sharq.com/news/details/412673] He studied sculpture at the Institute of Fine Arts in Baghdad and graduated from with a Diploma of Sculpture in 1988, Bahrani, Z. and Shabout, N.M., ''Modernism and Iraq,'' Miriam and Ira D. Wallach Art Gallery and Columbia University, 2009, p. 92 where he was influenced by many professors, notably Abdul Rahim Al Wakil.Ayoub, D., "His latest works return to "Calila and Damna" Ahmed Bahrani: Arab sculptor restricted creativity," ''Emaratalyoum,'' [Dubai], 1 February, 2012, [https://www.emaratalyoum.com/life/four-sides/2012-06-02-1.488713 Online:] He has participated in several exhibitions, ''Inside and Outside Iraq, Sculpture'' in Iraq and Yemen as well as his participation in several exhibitions in Qatar, [[Beirut]] and the [[UAE]]. His sculpture is on public display in several cities.''Alkahaki News,'' (translated from Arabic), [http://www.alhakikanews.com/index.php/permalink/21673.html]"Exhibition - Ahmed Bahrani at "Art Basel Gallery" Miami version sculpts terrorists and in his hand to save life from misunderstanding" (translated from Arabic), ''Annahar'' [newspaper], [https://newspaper.annahar.com/article/73940-%D9%85%D8%B9%D8%B1%D8%B6--%D8%A3%D8%AD%D9%85%D8%AF-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A8%D8%AD%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%8A-%D9%81%D9%8A-%D9%85%D8%B9%D8%B1%D8%B6-%D8%A2%D8%B1%D8%AA-%D8%A8%D8%A7%D8%B2%D9%84-%D9%86%D8%B3%D8%AE%D8%A9-%D9%85%D9%8A%D8%A7%D9%85%D9%8A-%D9%8A%D9%86%D8%AD%D8%AA-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A5%D8%B1%D9%87%D8%A7%D8%A8%D9%8A%D9%8A%D9%86-%D9%88%D9%81%D9%8A-%D8%A8%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%87-%D8%A3%D9%86-%D9%8A%D9%86%D9%82%D8%B0 Online:] He taught at the Baghdad Institute of Fine Arts between 1992 and 1994. In mid-career, he decided to move away from the endlesss pursuit of abstraction and began producing figurative works. However, more recently he has returned to abstract sculpture. In 1994, he left Iraq for political reasons, and lived in Amman, Jordan for a number of years and later resided in Yemen. Since 1999, he has divided his time between Doha in Qatar and Stockholm in Sweden. "The Iraqi sculptor Ahmad Al-Bahrani told Asharq Al-Awsat: I am part of Qatari culture and am proud," [Interview - translated from Arabic], ''Al Sharq,'' 2 April, 2016, [https://www.al-sharq.com/news/details/412673; Nangiana, U., "Talking Sculptures," ''Gulf Times,'' 13 March, 2016, [http://www.gulf-times.com/story/484374/Talking-sculptures Online:] == Work == Al Bahrani's work comprises large scale sculptures of political, religious and popular figures, often carrying various type of armaments."Ahmed Al- Bahrani," ''Wall Street Journal Magazine,'' 27 December, 2013, [https://wsimag.com/art/6676-ahmed-al-bahrani-war-to-war Online:] Like many of his contemporaries who are living in exile,The Ministry of Culture has estimated that more than 80 percent of all Iraqi artists are now living in exile,; See: ''Art AsiaPacific Almanac,'' Volume 4, Art AsiaPacific, 2009, p. 75 Al Bahrani uses his work to express the sense that he is "estranged from his geographical foundation and his roots." Nangiana, U., "Talking Sculptures," ''Gulf Times,'' 13 March, 2016, [http://www.gulf-times.com/story/484374/Talking-sculptures Online:] The sculptor has designed a collection of statues, monuments and murals in [[Baghdad]] and cities of the world. His most notable works include: * ''Green Art'' – [[Dubai]]. * Bisan Hall – Sponsored by the French Cultural Center – Qatar. * Al Bada Hall – National Council for Culture, Arts and Heritage – Qatar. * Al Fardan Gardens, sponsored by Alfardan Group – Qatar. * House of the French Ambassador – Qatar. * French Cultural Center – [[Sana'a]]. * Al Afif Hall – [[Sana'a]]. * ''The Challenge,'' bronze installation for the 24th Men's Handball World Championship, Lusail Multipurpose Hall, Doha, Qatar, 2015http://www.qm.org.qa/en/blog/challenge-and-other-public-art"The 2017 World Handball Championship is designed and manufactured by Ahmad Bahrani," ''Reyada News,'' 27 January, 2017 [http://www.reyada.com/news/2017/01/27/685010/articles/910667/%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B9%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%82%D9%8A-%D8%A3%D8%AD%D9%85%D8%AF-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A8%D8%AD%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%8A-%D9%8A%D8%AC%D8%B3%D8%AF-%D8%A5%D8%A8%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B9%D9%87-%D9%81%D9%8A-%D8%B5%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%B9%D8%A9-%D9%83%D8%A3%D8%B3 Online:] * Gulf Cooperation Council Cup * ''Olympic Rings,'' Khalifa International Stadium, Doha, Qatar * Bayfront Park, Miami, Florida, Nine sculptures including Charlie Chaplin, Mother Theresa and Michael Jackson, 2014 * ''Monument of [[Abu Tahsin al-Salhi]]''"Government of Basra commissioned the sculptor Ahmad Bahrani to erect a monument commemorating (Ain Falcon)," ''Almirbad,'' 18 October, 2017, [http://www.almirbad.com/news/view.aspx?cdate=18102017&id=b1501ab3-887f-48fd-90a5-3589a2e04bdf Online:] * ''Cube: A Message of Peace,'' 1.5m bronze, Hamad International Airport, Doha Doha Hammad Airport, [https://dohahamadairport.com/relax/art-exhibitions/a-message-of-peace-to-the-world-by-Iraqi-artist-ahmed-al-bahrani Online:] * ''La Ferrari,'' bronze sculpture of the Ferrari motor vehicle, Lobby of St. Regis, Doha, 2016 Barker, M., "The Right Profile," ''Ferrari Magazine,'' 20 October, 2016 [http://magazine.ferrari.com/en/living/2016/10/20/news/a_laferrari_in_bronze-18062/ Online:] {{Infobox officeholder | name = Aleksandar Lilov
Александър Лилов | image = | office1 = Chairman of the [[Bulgarian Socialist Party]] | term_start1 =3 April 1990 | term_end1 = December 1991 | predecessor1 = Himself as Chairman of the BCP | successor1 = [[Zhan Videnov]] | office2 = Chairman of the [[Bulgarian Communist Party]] | term_start2= 2 February 1990 | term_end2= 3 April 1990 | predecessor2 = [[Petar Mladenov]] (as General Secretary) | successor2= Himself as Chairman of the BSP | birth_name = Aleksandar Vasilev Lilov
Александър Василев Лилов | birth_date = 31 August 1933 | birth_place = [[Granichak (village)|Granichak]], [[Kingdom of Bulgaria|Bulgaria]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2013|7|20|1933|8|31|df=y}} | death_place = [[Sofia]], [[Republic of Bulgaria|Bulgaria]] | party = [[Bulgarian Socialist Party]] (1990-2013) | otherparty = [[Bulgarian Communist Party]] (until 1990) | alma_mater = [[Sofia University]] (philosophy) | signature = BASA-117-46-1084-74-Signature of Aleksandar Lilov (cropped).jpg }} '''Aleksandër Vasilev Lilov''' ({{lang-bg|Александър Василев Лилов}}; 31 August 1933 – 20 July 2013) was a [[Bulgaria]]n politician and philosopher. At his career's height during the [[People's Republic of Bulgaria]], he was described as the second most powerful man of the regime. However, he fell out of favor in 1983 and lost his power. He made a strong political comeback during the democratic transition and was elected chairman of the [[Bulgarian Communist Party]]. He led the party to transform and adapt to the post-communist era. A party referendum supported his proposal to change the name to the [[Bulgarian Socialist Party]]. After winning the first [[Bulgarian Constitutional Assembly election, 1990|democratic elections]] he did not become prime minister himself, instead he eventually supported a multi-party government led by [[Dimitar Iliev Popov|Dimitar Popov]]. After losing the [[Bulgarian parliamentary election, 1991|1991 parliamentary elections]] he stepped down as party leader. In 2001 he retired as MP after having served for 39 years. ==Biography== Aleksandar Lilov was born on 31 August 1933 in the village of [[Granichak (village)|Granichak]], northwestern [[Vidin Province]]. He graduated Bulgarian Studies (philosophy) at [[Sofia University]] in 1962 and graduated doctoral studies in communist Social Science at the Academy of Public Sciences in Moscow. In 1975 he became an associate at the institution of art at the [[Bulgarian Academy of Sciences]]. Six years later, he defended a doctoral thesis in 1981. He died on 20 July 2013 at the age of 79. ==Political career== Lilov joined the Dimitrov Young Communist League in Vidin and rose to the ranks of its central committee in 1963. Six years later he joined the central Party organ and in 1971 he became a prominent member of the Communist Party. Lilov was a member of the Politburo of the Central Committee of the [[Bulgarian Communist Party]] from July 1974 to September 1983 and was also a secretary of the Central Committee of the Party from July 1972 to September 28, 1983. He was also a member of the [[State Council of Bulgaria]] from 1976 to 1983. By the end of the 70s he was viewed as the second most powerful member of the party. After the death of [[Lyudmila Zhivkova]] (General Secretary [[Todor Zhivkov]]'s daughter) in 1981, Lilov's power began to wane. In 1983 he was removed from the Politburo after criticizing the General Secretary for his economic mismanagement and apparent lack of interest in current issues. After fading from the public view for six year, Lilov returned from Great-Britain - where he was when Zhivkov was forced to resign on November 10, 1989 - and was welcomed back among the leaders of the BCP. There he denounced the [[Revival Process]] (started by Zhivkov and internationally condemned) and allowed Bulgarian Muslims to reinstate their former names. During the 14th emergency congress of the Bulgarian Communist Party (held in January - February 1990), the post of general secretary was abolished, and Lilov was elected to the new post of chairman. Under his leadership the party was dissolved and reorganized into the [[Bulgarian Socialist Party]] on April 3 following an party referendum. This transition brought about revolutionary change to the party's ideology, from Communism to Socialism (from [[far-left politics|far-left]] to [[left-wing politics|left-wing]]). Change was also brought to the way the party was run in order to dismantle the totalitarian apparatus in the country. In September he was reelected as party chairman by a margin of 2 to 1 against the hopes of the liberals in the party who sought to remove the remains of the former Communist regime.{{cite web|title=WORLD : Bulgaria Socialists Reelect Lilov|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-09-25/news/mn-1340_1_socialist-party|work=World News|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=25 September 1990|accessdate=9 February 2014}} He remained the party's leader until the end of 1991. He led the Socialists through the first democratic elections in [[Bulgarian Constitutional Assembly election, 1990|1990]], elected to adopt a new constitution, where his party won a majority of the seats (211 out of 400) and 47.15% of the votes. He did not become Prime Minister himself, instead continuing his support for the socialist government in place led by [[Andrey Lukanov]]. This came to an end when mass demonstrations and a general strike led to the formation of a government under the non-partisan judge [[Dimitar Iliev Popov|Dimitar Popov]] in which the BSP participated alongside the [[Union of Democratic Forces (Bulgaria)|UDF]], [[Bulgarian Agrarian National Union|BANU]] and independent experts. His second election campaign in [[Bulgarian parliamentary election, 1991|1991]] ended with defeat after his electoral alliance won only 33.1% of the votes and 106 seats (out of 240); finishing behind the [[Union of Democratic Forces (Bulgaria)|Union of Democratic Forces]] who won 34.4% of the votes and 110 seats. Later that year he stepped down and as chairman of the party and was succeeded by [[Zhan Videnov]]. Lilov remained a Member of Parliament until 2001, a seat he held for 39 years (1962–2001). In 2001 he was the longest serving member of parliament. ==References== {{Reflist|refs= |{{cite web|title=Bulgaria Socialist Party Ex Chair Alexander Lilov Dies at 79|url=http://www.novinite.com/view_news.php?id=152209|work=Novinite.com|publisher=Sofia News Agency|accessdate=9 February 2014}} {{cite web|title=Александър Лилов|url=http://archives.bg/politburo/bg/component/content/article/48-chlenovenapb/94-2012-01-04-15-09-26|work=Протоколи на Политбюро и на Цк на БКП (1944-1989)|publisher=Аrchives.bg|accessdate=9 February 2014}} ('''Bulgarian''') }} {{Leaders of the Ruling Parties of the Eastern Bloc}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lilov, Alexander}} [[Category:1933 births]] [[Category:2013 deaths]] [[Category:People from Vidin Province]] [[Category:20th-century philosophers]] [[Category:Bulgarian philosophers]] [[Category:Bulgarian politicians]] [[Category:Philosophers of art]] [[Category:Bulgarian Communist Party politicians]] [[Category:Bulgarian socialists]] [[Category:Bulgarian Socialist Party politicians]] [[Category:Members of the National Assembly (Bulgaria)]] [[Category:20th-century Bulgarian politicians]] [[Category:Sofia University alumni]]

{{more citations needed|date=May 2013}}
The '''antiquities trade''' is the exchange of [[antiquities]] and [[Artifact (archaeology)|archaeological artifacts]] from around the world. This trade may be [[wikt:illicit|illicit]] or completely legal. The legal antiquities trade abide by national regulations, which now universally provides for extraction that allows for the scientific study of the artifacts in order to study the archaeological and anthropological context.{{citation needed|date=May 2013}}{{clarify|date=May 2013}} The illicit antiquities trade involves non-scientific extraction that ignores the [[Archaeology|archaeological]] and [[Anthropology|anthropological]] context from the artifacts.
==Legal trade== The legal trade in antiquities abide by the laws of the countries in which the artifacts originate. These laws establish how the antiquities may be extracted from the ground and the legal process in which artifacts may leave the country. In many countries excavations and exports were prohibited without official licenses already in the 19th century, as for example in the Ottoman Empire. According to the laws of the countries of origin, there can't be a legal trade with archaeological artifact without official papers. However, most national laws still overturn these regulations.
==Illicit trade== {{see also|Art theft|Looted art}} Illicit or illegal antiquities are those found in illegal or unregulated excavations, and traded covertly.<ref>[http://traffickingculture.org/encyclopedia/terminology/illicit-antiquities Illicit Antiquities], Trafficking Culture Encyclopedia.</ref> The [[black market]] trade of illicit antiquities is supplied by [[looting]] and [[art theft]]. Artifacts are often those that have been discovered and unearthed at archeological digs and then transported internationally through a middleman to often unsuspecting collectors, museums, antique dealers, and auction houses.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Amineddoleh|first=Leila|date=2013-10-01|title=The Role of Museums in the Trade of Black Market Cultural Heritage Property|url=https://papers.ssrn.com/abstract=2370699|location=Rochester, NY}}</ref> The antiquities trade is much more careful in recent years about establishing the [[provenance]] of cultural artifacts.<ref>[http://www.archaeology.org/online/interviews/atwood.html Archaeological Institute of America]</ref><ref name="news.bbc.co.uk">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/3392057.stm BBC]</ref> Some estimates put annual turnover in billions of US dollars.
It is believed by many archaeologists and cultural heritage lawyers that the demand created by circulation, marketing, and collectorship of ancient artifacts causes the continuous looting and destruction of archaeological sites around the world.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/islamic-state-antiquities-trade-stretches-europe-united-states-1724733|title=Islamic State Antiquities Trade Stretches To Europe, United States|date=2014-11-17|work=International Business Times|access-date=2017-12-28}}</ref><ref>See {{cite journal | last1 = Brodie | first1 = Neil | last2 = Renfrew | first2 = Colin | year = 2005 | title = Looting and the world's archaeological heritage: the inadequate response | url = http://traffickingculture.org/publications/brodie-n-and-renfrew-c-2005-looting-and-the-worlds-archaeological-heritage-the-inadequate-response-annual-review-of-anthropology-34-343-61| journal = Annual Review of Anthropology | volume = 34 | issue = | pages = 343–61 | doi = 10.1146/annurev.anthro.34.081804.120551 }}</ref> Archaeological artifacts are internationally protected by the [[Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict]] and their circulation is prohibited by the [[UNESCO Convention on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property|UNESCO Convention (1970) on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property]].
Examples of looting of archaeological sites for the black market: *[[Archaeological looting in Iraq]] *[[Archaeological looting in Romania]] *[[Maya stelae#Looting|Maya stelae looting]] * Archaeological looting in Peru <ref>Alva, W., 2001. The destruction, looting and traffic of the archaeological heritage of Peru, in Brodie, N.J., Doole, J., Renfrew, C. (eds). 2001. Trade in illicit antiquities: the destruction of the world’s archaeological heritage. Cambridge: McDonald Institute, pp. 89-96</ref>
=== Response === Recent trends reveal a large push to repatriate [[Artifact (archaeology)|artifacts]] illicitly extracted and traded on the international market. Such artifacts include those held by museums like the [[Getty Museum]]<ref>See e.g. [http://traffickingculture.org/encyclopedia/case-studies/j-paul-getty-museum-returns-to-italy-1999 J Paul Getty Museum Returns to Italy 1999], [http://traffickingculture.org/encyclopedia/case-studies/j-paul-getty-museum-returns-to-italy-2005 J Paul Getty Museum Returns to Italy (2005)], and [http://traffickingculture.org/encyclopedia/case-studies/j-paul-getty-museum-returns-to-italy-2007 J. Paul Getty Museum Returns to Italy (2007)], Trafficking Culture Encyclopedia.</ref> and the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]].<ref>See e.g. [http://traffickingculture.org/encyclopedia/case-studies/euphronios-sarpedon-krater Euphronios (Sarpedon) Krater], Trafficking Culture Encyclopedia.</ref> In order to solve the phenomenon of looting, aerial surveillance - the effectiveness of which depends on the capability to perform systematic prospections - is increasingly being used. Nevertheless, it is impractical in several countries due to military activity, political restrictions, and/or huge areas and difficult environmental settings (desert, rain forest, etc..). In these contexts, space technology could offer a suitable chance as in the case of Peru. In this country an Italian scientific mission directed by [[Nicola Masini]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-16190824|title=Protecting Peru's ancient past|last=Cabitza|first=Mattia|date=2011-12-15|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-12-28|language=en-GB}}</ref> since 2008 have been using very high resolution satellite data to observe and monitor the phenomeno of 'huaqueros' in some archaeological areas in Southern and Northern Peru.<ref>Lasaponara R., Masini N. R. 2010, Facing the archaeological looting in Peru by local spatial autocorrelation statistics of Very high resolution satellite imagery, Proceedings of ICSSA, The 2010 International Conference on Computational Science and its Application (Fukuoka-Japan, March 23 – 26, 2010), Springer, Berlin, pp. 261-269;</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Lasaponara | first1 = R. | last2 = Leucci | first2 = G. | last3 = Masini | first3 = N. | last4 = Persico | first4 = R. | year = 2014 | title = Investigating archaeological looting using satellite images and georadar: the experience in Lambayeque in North Peru | doi = 10.1016/j.jas.2013.10.032 | journal = Journal of Archaeological Science | volume = 42 | issue = | pages = 216–230 }}</ref>

'''Bill Silva Entertainment''' is a concert promotion, artist management, touring, and publishing company based in [[Los Angeles]] and established in 1979.<ref name="celebrityaccess.com">[http://celebrityaccess.com/members/profile.html?id=538 "CelebrityAccess Industry Profiles"]. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref><ref name="renmanmb.com">{{Cite web |url=http://www.renmanmb.com/live/guests/bill-silva |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-02-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150129032832/http://www.renmanmb.com/live/guests/bill-silva |archive-date=2015-01-29 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>=http://digitalmediasummit.ca/wp-content/plugins/cmw-speakers/speaker_details.php?id=25</ref>
BSE has represented artists such as [[Jason Mraz]], [[blink-182]], [[Unwritten Law]], [[James Morrison (singer)|James Morrison]], and [[Christina Perri]], and has produced more than 10,000 shows.<ref name="renmanmb.com"/> Bill Silva, the company's founder, has won three Independent Promoter of the Year awards.<ref>Pollstar Creative Services [http://www.pollstarpro.com/PCIA-Static/welcome.htm "Pollstar Awards Archive"]. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref>
The company is a partner in DT Model Management<ref name="emc|bowery">EMC|BOWERY. [http://www.prlog.org/12000086-international-agent-david-todd-opens-dt-model-management.html "International Agent David Todd Opens DT Model Management"]. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref> and The Uprising Creative.
== History ==
=== Early Years: San Diego === While Bill Silva was a student at University of San Diego he started a concert promotion company for university parties. This led him to expand into the San Diego area and establish Bill Silva Presents in 1979. Over the next two decades the company brought acts such as [[The Who]], [[Simon & Garfunkel]], [[Devo]], [[The Police]], [[Pat Benatar]], [[INXS]], [[Diana Ross]], and [[Willie Nelson]] to the area.<ref name="celebrityaccess.com"/><ref name="renmanmb.com"/><ref name="digitalmediasummit.ca">http://digitalmediasummit.ca/wp-content/plugins/cmw-speakers/speaker_details.php?id=25</ref>
After securing a foothold in San Diego, Silva branched out into other parts of the southwest, promoting smaller shows in Arizona, Texas, Nevada, and Idaho. In 1982 he partnered with Feyline Productions and became the promoter for any of Feyline's shows outside of Colorado.<ref name="renmanmb.com"/>
In 1992 Silva teamed up with Andrew Hewitt to obtain exclusive rights to produce rock concerts at the [[Hollywood Bowl]].<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/1992-08-23/news/mn-7298_1_hollywood-bowl "Hollywood Bowl Deal Questioned by Promoters"]. ''latimes''. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref>
In 1993 Silva started representing the band [[Unwritten Law]]<ref>[http://www.allmusic.com/artist/bill-silva-mn0001881067 "Bill Silva"]. ''AllMusic''. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref> after promoting one of their shows and BSE's management division, Bill Silva Management, was founded. Soon after, BSM added [[Blink-182]] to its artist roster.<ref name="renmanmb.com"/>
=== The Move To Los Angeles and the Start of the Jason Mraz Era ===
Bill Silva Entertainment moved from San Diego to Los Angeles in 1999.<ref name="celebrityaccess.com"/><ref name="renmanmb.com"/> He was introduced to [[Jason Mraz]], who he managed until 2017.<ref name="celebrityaccess.com"/><ref name="renmanmb.com"/><ref name="digitalmediasummit.ca"/><ref>https://www.sandiegoreader.com/news/2017/sep/12/blurt-jason-mraz-breaks-manager-bill-silva/</ref>
Silva also sold his concert division, Bill Silva Presents, to Universal Studios's concert division, which was later purchased by House of Blues Concerts. In March 2003 Andrew Hewitt and Silva left that venture, parting ways in concert promotion with the exception of their partnership at the Hollywood Bowl.<ref name="celebrityaccess.com"/><ref name="digitalmediasummit.ca"/>
Silva went on to re-establish Bill Silva Presents with a touring division that was kicked off by 2000's "Up In Smoke Tour" with [[Dr. Dre]], [[Snoop Dogg]], and [[Eminem]].<ref name="celebrityaccess.com"/><ref name="renmanmb.com"/><ref name="digitalmediasummit.ca"/> In 2005 Silva hired Eric Herz, a former executive at Avalon Attractions and Metropolitan Entertainment, to oversee Bill Silva Presents.<ref>[http://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/3501/herz-joins-bill-silva-presents "Herz Joins Bill Silva Presents"]. ''All Access''. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref>
=== Recent Years: Expansion and Diversification === In 2011 Silva merged Bill Silva Presents with Live Nation Entertainment, placing Silva and Andrew Hewitt in charge of overseeing the company's concerts in the southwest region of the United States.<ref>George Varga (26 October 2011). [http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2011/Oct/26/live-nation-teams-bill-silva/ "Live Nation teams up with Bill Silva"]. ''The San Diego Union-Tribune''. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref>
In 2012 the Bill Silva Entertainment team formed a partnership with the model manager David Todd to form DT Model Management.<ref name="emc|bowery"/>
== Bill Silva Management == Bill Silva Management has managed the careers of artists, comedians, and film directors since its founding in 1993.
The company began with San Diego bands Unwritten Law and blink-182, and managed [[Jason Mraz]] from 1999 to 2017.<ref name="celebrityaccess.com"/><ref name="renmanmb.com"/><ref name="digitalmediasummit.ca"/><ref name="theuprisingcreative">The Uprising Creative. [http://www.billsilvaentertainment.com/management/ "Bill Silva Entertainment"]. ''Bill Silva Entertainment''. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref><ref>https://www.sandiegoreader.com/news/2017/sep/12/blurt-jason-mraz-breaks-manager-bill-silva/</ref>
Until 2008 Silva also managed and promoted tours for comedian [[Margaret Cho]].<ref name="celebrityaccess.com"/><ref name="digitalmediasummit.ca"/><ref>[http://legacy.utsandiego.com/news/features/20060521-9999-1a21varga.html "SignOnSanDiego.com > News > Features -- Hetfield and Silva honored at L.A. benefit concert"]. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref>
In 2010 BSM client [[Christina Perri]]'s demo "Jar of Hearts" was featured on FOX's ''[[So You Think You Can Dance]],'' and was successful on the Billboard, iTunes, and Amazon charts.<ref>[http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/music/news/2010-07-10-christina-perri_N.htm?csp=34 "Christina Perri pries open the lid to fame with 'Jar of Hearts' - USATODAY.com"]. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref>
The company currently represents [[Molly Kate Kestner]],<ref name="theuprisingcreative" /> [[Brooke Candy]],<ref name="theuprisingcreative" /> [[Dreezy]],<ref name="theuprisingcreative"/> [[Kittens (band)|Kittens]],<ref name="theuprisingcreative"/> [[XO-IQ]].<ref name="theuprisingcreative" />
== Silva Music Publishing == The publishing division of BSE began as a service for its management clients, primarily dealing with BSM artists and their collaborators.<ref name="celebrityaccess.com"/> In 2012 the company brought in Peter Coquillard, a music publisher who previously worked with Windswept Pacific, L.A. Reid, HITCO, and Network One Music Publishing, to expand the publishing division to include songwriters unaffiliated with BSM.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.songsummit.com.au/program/speakers-artists/peter-coquillard/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-02-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306221059/http://www.songsummit.com.au/program/speakers-artists/Peter-Coquillard/ |archivedate=2016-03-06 |df= }}</ref>
Silva Music Publishing consists of three publishing entities: Silva Tone Music (ASCAP),<ref>[https://www.ascap.com/Home/ace-title-search/index.aspx "ACE Title Search"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130306032310/https://www.ascap.com/Home/ace-title-search/index.aspx |date=March 6, 2013 }}. ''www.ascap.com''. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref> BS Management Music (BMI),<ref>http://repertoire.bmi.com/publisher.asp?blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&keyID=861799&keyname=BS+MANAGEMENT+MUSIC&querytype=PubID{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and Silva Lining Music (SESAC).<ref>[http://www.sesac.com/Repertory/PublisherSearch.aspx "Repertory Search :: SESAC"]. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref>
Silva Tone consists of: * Ainslie Henderson, who wrote "Clockwatching" with Jason Mraz<ref>Ainslie Henderson. [http://www.musicaneo.com/sheetmusic/sm-121307_clockwatching_jason_mraz.html "Clockwatching (Jason Mraz)"]. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref> * Michael Natter, who wrote "I Won't Give Up" with Jason Mraz * Stephen "Shebby" Ruchelman, who wrote for Hollywood Undead and Neon Trees including the track "Some Kind of Monster," which was featured on the ''Iron Man 3'' soundtrack.<ref>[http://www.halleonard.com/product/viewproduct.do?itemid=8203121 "I Won't Give Up, Pop Choral Series - Hal Leonard Online"]. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref> * Tiffany Vartanyan, who has written with Ryan Tedder of One Republic and Demi Lovato<ref>[http://lybio.net/tag/tiffany-vartanyan/ "Tiffany Vartanyan"]. ''LYBIO.net Is A Movement For Internet Online Accuracy For Speeches, Text, Words, Quotes and Lyrics.''. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref>
BS Management Music publishes for: * John Hogan of Unwritten law<ref>http://repertoire.bmi.com/title.asp?blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&keyID=5985274&ShowNbr=0&ShowSeqNbr=0&querytype=WorkID{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * John Anderson, who wrote and performed with Christine Perri<ref>http://repertoire.bmi.com/title.asp?blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&keyID=12574331&ShowNbr=0&ShowSeqNbr=0&querytype=WorkID{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * David Pack of Ambrosia<ref>http://repertoire.bmi.com/title.asp?blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&keyID=115945&ShowNbr=0&ShowSeqNbr=0&querytype=WorkID{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Silva Lining Music currently publishes exclusively for Jeremy Thurber,<ref>[http://www.sesac.com/Repertory/SongSearch.aspx?songnum=785134 "Song Search :: SESAC"]. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref> a pop artist who has collaborated with Jake Miller<ref name="allmusic.com">[http://www.allmusic.com/song/peace-out-mt0045191011 "Peace Out"]. ''AllMusic''. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref> and Karl Wolf.<ref name="allmusic.com"/>

{{see also|Our Lady of Sorrows, Queen of Poland}} {{Infobox Catholic apparition |name = Black Madonna of Częstochowa
Our Lady of Częstochowa |image = NMP-Czestochowska-w-koronie.jpg |location = [[Częstochowa]], [[Poland]] |date = Attested as early as 14th century |type = Wooden icon, bejewelled |approval = [[Pope Clement XI]]
[[Pope Pius X]]
[[Pope John Paul II]] |shrine = [[Jasna Góra Monastery]], [[Częstochowa]], [[Poland]]
[[National Shrine of Our Lady of Czestochowa]], [[Doylestown, Pennsylvania]] |attributes = [[Black Madonna]] in [[Hodegetria]] form, [[Infant Jesus]], fleur-de-lis robes, slashes on right cheek |patronage = [[Poland]] }} The '''Black Madonna of Częstochowa''' ({{lang-pl|Czarna Madonna}} or {{lang|pl|Matka Boska Częstochowska|italic=yes}}, {{lang-la|Imago thaumaturga Beatae Virginis Mariae Immaculatae Conceptae, in Claro Monte}} ), also known as '''Our Lady of Częstochowa''', is a revered [[icon]] of the [[Mary (mother of Jesus)|Virgin Mary]] housed at the [[Jasna Góra Monastery]] in [[Częstochowa]], [[Poland]]. Several Pontiffs have recognised the venerated icon, beginning with [[Pope Clement XI]] who issued a [[Canonical Coronation]] to the image on 8 September 1717 via the Vatican Chapter. ==The icon== The four-foot-high painting displays a traditional composition well known in the icons of Eastern Christians. The Virgin Mary is shown as the "[[Hodegetria]]" ("One Who Shows the Way"). In it the Virgin directs attention away from herself, gesturing with her right hand toward Jesus as the source of salvation. In turn, the child extends his right hand toward the viewer in blessing while holding a book of gospels in his left hand. The icon shows the Madonna in [[fleur-de-lis]] robes. The origins of the icon and the date of its composition are still contested among scholars.[http://www.csicop.org/si/show/the_black_madonna_a_folkloristic_and_iconographic_investigation/ ''The Black Madonna: A Folkloristic and Iconographic Investigation''. Skeptical Inquirer. September/October 2015.] One difficulty in dating the icon is due in part to its original image being painted over after being badly damaged by [[Hussite]] raiders in 1430. The wooden boards that backed the painting were broken and the canvas slashed. [[Middle Ages|Medieval]] restorers unfamiliar with the [[encaustic painting|encaustic method]] found that the paints they applied to the damaged areas "simply sloughed off the image" according to the medieval chronicler Risinius, and their solution was to erase the original image and to repaint it on the original panel. The original features of an Orthodox icon were softened; the nose was made more aquiline. ==History== [[File:Nuestra Señora de Czestochowa recubierta de Orfebrería.jpg|thumb|The image of the Holy Virgin of Częstochowa (before 1714). The collection of [[Radomysl Castle]][http://www.radozamok.com.ua/en/ The Official Site of Radomysl Castle]]] ===Lucan tradition=== The icon of [[Blessed Virgin Mary|Our Lady]] of Częstochowa has been intimately associated with Poland for the past 600 years. Its history prior to its arrival in Poland is shrouded in numerous legends which trace the icon's origin to [[Luke the Evangelist|St. Luke]] who painted it on a cedar table top from the house of the [[Holy Family]].{{cite web|url=https://udayton.edu/imri/mary/c/czestochowa-black-madonna.php|title=Black Madonnas: Our Lady of Czestochowa|date=2008-03-26|last=Duricy|first=Michael P|publisher=The Marian Library/International Marian Research Institute, Dayton, Ohio - [[University of Dayton]]|accessdate=2008-12-05}} {{cite news| author=Zenon Zawada| work=Ukraine Observer| title=EASTERN APPROACHES - The Black Madonna|url=http://www.ukraine-observer.com/articles/217/814 | date=2008-01-26|accessdate=2008-12-05 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080126124229/http://www.ukraine-observer.com/articles/217/814 |archivedate = 2008-01-26}} The same legend holds that the painting was discovered in Jerusalem in 326 by St. [[Helena (empress)|Helena]], who brought it back to [[Constantinople]] and presented it to her son, [[Constantine the Great]].[http://www.franciscancaring.org/blackmadonnashri.html#ABriefHistory "Black Madonna Shrine", Franciscan Missionary Brothers] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140829025421/http://www.franciscancaring.org/blackmadonnashri.html#ABriefHistory |date=August 29, 2014 }} ===Arrival in Częstochowa=== The oldest documents from [[Jasna Góra Monastery|Jasna Góra]] state that the picture travelled from Constantinople via [[Belz]]. Eventually it came into the possession of [[Vladislaus II of Opole|Władysław Opolczyk]], [[Duke of Opole]], and adviser to [[Louis I of Hungary|Louis of Anjou]], King of Poland and Hungary. Ukrainian sources state that earlier in its history it was brought to Belz with much ceremony and honors by King [[Leo I of Galicia|Lev I of Galicia]] and later taken by Władysław from the Castle of Belz, when the town was incorporated into the Polish kingdom. A popular story tells that in late August 1384, Ladislaus was passing Częstochowa with the picture when his horses refused to go on. He was advised in a dream to leave the icon at Jasna Gora. Art historians say that the original painting was a Byzantine icon created around the sixth or ninth century. They agree that Prince Władysław brought it to the monastery in the 14th century.[http://www.polamjournal.com/Library/APHistory/blackmadonna/blackmadonna.html "The Black Madonna of Czestochowa", ''Polish American Journal''] ==Pontifical approbations== Several Pontiffs have recognized the image, namely the following: * [[Pope Clement XI]] issued a [[Canonical Coronation]] for the image through the Vatican Chapter on 8 September 1717 * [[Pope Pius X]], after the crowns were stolen on 23 October 1909, the Pontiff replaced the crowns on 22 May 1910. * [[Pope John Paul II]] gifted another set of crowns as a native of Poland, which was placed on 26 August 2005. ===Coronation as Queen and Protectress of Poland=== In August 1382 the hilltop parish church was transferred to the Paulites, a hermitic order from Hungary. The golden fleur-de-lis painted on the Virgin's blue veil parallel the heraldic ''azure, semée de lis, or'' of the French royal coat of arms and the most likely explanation for their presence is that the icon had been present in Hungary during the reign of either [[Charles I of Hungary]] and/or [[Louis the Great]], the Hungarian kings of the [[Anjou]] dynasty, who probably had the fleur-de-lis of their family's coat of arms painted on the icon. This would suggest that the icon was probably originally brought to Jasna Gora by the Pauline monks from their founding monastery in Hungary. The Black Madonna is said to have miraculously saved the monastery of Jasna Góra (English: Bright Mount) from a Swedish invasion. The Siege of Jasna Góra took place in the winter of 1655 during the [[Second Northern War]], as the Swedish invasion of the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]] is known. The Swedes were attempting to capture the Jasna Góra monastery in Częstochowa. Seventy monks and 180 local volunteers, mostly from the szlachta (Polish nobility), held off 4,000 Swedes for 40 days, saved their sacred icon and, according to some accounts, turned the course of the war. This event led King [[John II Casimir Vasa]] to "crown" Our Lady of Częstochowa ("the [[Black Madonna]]") as [[Lwów Oath|Queen and Protector of Poland]] in the cathedral of [[Lviv|Lwów]] on April 1, 1652. Prior to this event, several royal nobilities have offered crowns to the image throughout the years, replacing its iron sheet crown by gold and several jewels. In later years, various jewels were interchanged and repositioned around the image to preserve the aesthetic of the icon with the replacement of stolen crowns.http://sunday.niedziela.pl/artykul.php?dz=polska&id_art=00163 ===Legends about the Madonna's appearance=== {{RC-Mariology}} [[File:Jasna Gora - Czarna Madonna (mozaika).jpg|thumb|right|Black Madonna mosaic at Jasna Góra.]] The legend concerning the two scars on the Black Madonna's right cheek is that the [[Hussite]]s stormed the Pauline monastery in 1430, plundering the sanctuary. Among the items stolen was the icon. After putting it in their wagon, the Hussites tried to get away but their horses refused to move. They threw the portrait down to the ground and one of the plunderers drew his sword upon the image and inflicted two deep strikes. When the robber tried to inflict a third strike, he fell to the ground and writhed in agony until his death. Despite past attempts to repair these scars, they had difficulty in covering up those slashes as the painting was done with tempera infused with diluted wax. ===Veneration=== Częstochowa is regarded as the most popular shrine in Poland, with many Polish Catholics making a pilgrimage there every year. A pilgrimage has left Warsaw every August 6 since 1711 for the nine-day, 140-mile trek. Elderly pilgrims recall stealing through the dark countryside at great personal risk during the German Nazi occupation. Pope John Paul II secretly visited as a student pilgrim during World War II.[https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/22/travel/poland-s-black-madonna.html Menaker, Drusilla. "Poland's Black Madonna", ''New York Times'', July 22, 1990] The feast day of Our Lady of Częstochowa is celebrated on August 26.{{Citation needed|date=August 2015}} The American [[National Shrine of Our Lady of Czestochowa]] is located in Doylestown, Pennsylvania.[http://www.czestochowa.us/content/view/1319/65/ "National Shrine of Our Lady of Czestochowa] ==In other countries== [[File:Jasnajf.JPG|thumb|200px|Black Madonna of Częstochowa (at [[National Shrine of The Divine Mercy, Philippines]]).]] Orthodox Christians are also aware of the Black Madonna of Częstochowa and venerate her. The icon is popular in Ukraine and Belarus as former parts of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth and even in Russia. Moreover, this icon has an Orthodox origin, but Polish historians have found out it has been repainted at least twice and there is almost nothing left of the previous Byzantine manner of painting.A. Różycka-Bryzek, J. Gadomski, Obraz Matki Boskiej Częstochowskiej w świetle badań historii sztuki, "Studia Claromontana" 5, 1984, s. 27-52 [[Ukrainians]] have a special devotion for the Madonna of Częstochowa. The icon is often mentioned in Ukrainian folk songs from the 16th and 17th centuries. ==See also== * [[Black Madonna]] * [[Jasna Góra Monastery]] * [[Black Madonna Shrine, Missouri]] * [[National Shrine of Our Lady of Czestochowa|National Shrine of Our Lady of Częstochowa]] * [[Orthodox Church of the Icon of Our Lady of Częstochowa]] * [[Deluge (history)|The Deluge]], Swedish invasion * [[Our Lady of Sorrows, Queen of Poland]] * [[Erzulie Dantor]] ==References and sources== ===References=== {{reflist|2}} ===Sources=== * {{cite web|url=http://www.jasnagora.pl|title=Jasna Góra|publisher=[[copyright|©]]1998-2008 Copyright by Klasztor OO. Paulinów Jasna Góra - Częstochowa |accessdate=October 22, 2008}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.ksiegarnia.bernardinum.com.pl/Czestochowska_Hodegetria-170.html|title=Częstochowska Hodegetria|last=[[:pl:Wojciech Kurpik|Kurpik, Wojciech]]|first=|publisher=Wydawnictwo Konserwatorów Dzieł Sztuki, Wydawnictwo Bernardinum |location=Łódź-Pelplin|year=2008 |pages=302|language=Polish, English, Hungarian}} ==External links== {{commons category|Black Madonna of Częstochowa}} * [http://www.jasnagora.pl/ Jasna Góra] * [http://www.czestochowa.us/ Czestochowa.us] * [[:pl:Wojciech Kurpik|biographical entry of prof. dr Wojciech Kurpik, restorer of Black Madonna of Częstochowa (Polish Wikipedia)]] {{National symbols of Poland}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Black Madonna Of Czestochowa, The}} [[Category:Częstochowa]] [[Category:Marian shrines]] [[Category:Catholic Church in Poland]] [[Category:Catholic devotions]] [[Category:Black Madonna of Częstochowa| ]] [[Category:Titles of Mary]] [[Category:National symbols of Poland]] [[Category:Eastern Orthodox icons of the Virgin Mary]] [[Category:Paintings of the Madonna and Child]] [[Category:Pauline Order]] [[Category:Angels in art]]

{{Infobox Website | name = BookLikes | logo = BookLikes Logo.png | logocaption = | screenshot = | collapsible = | collapsetext = | caption = | url = {{URL|booklikes.com}} | commercial = | type = Catalog and community | registration = Free | language = [[English language|English]], [[German language|German]], [[Polish language|Polish]] | content license = | owner = Dawid Piaskowski, Joanna Grzelak-Piaskowska | author = Dawid Piaskowski, Joanna Grzelak-Piaskowska | launch date = {{Start date and age|2013|05|df=yes/no}} | alexa = {{decrease}}140,584<ref name = "BookLikes Alexa Ranking">{{cite web | title=BookLikes Alexa Ranking | url = http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/booklikes.com | publisher= [[Alexa Internet|Alexa]] | accessdate= 20 October 2013}}</ref> | revenue = | current status = Active | footnotes = }}
'''BookLikes''' is a "[[social cataloging]]" website founded in June 2011 by [[Dawid Piaskowski]], a software engineer, e-business analyst and entrepreneur, and [[Joanna Grzelak-Piaskowska]], a linguist and literary scholar.<ref name = "BookLikes: Company Info/Keyfacts">{{cite web | title= Keyfacts | url = http://booklikes.com/press/29/keyfacts | work = BookLikes | accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref>{{primary source inline|date=December 2016}}<ref name = "BookLikes: Company Info/Timeline">{{cite web | title= Timeline | url = http://booklikes.com/press/27/timeline | work = BookLikes | accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref>{{primary source inline|date=December 2016}}<ref name = "BookLikes: Company Info/Team">{{cite web | title= Team | url = http://booklikes.com/press/28/team | work = BookLikes | accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref>{{primary source inline|date=December 2016}} The website allows individuals to freely search BookLikes' database of books and reviews. Users can sign up and register books to generate library catalogs. They can also create their own groups of book suggestions and discussions.
Within eight months of beta testing prior to the May 14, 2013 public launch of the website in its current form, it gathered 8000 bloggers.<ref name="LitReactor: New Book Social Media Site 'BookLikes' Now Open (May 17, 2013)">{{cite web | title= New Book Social Media Site 'BookLikes' Now Open | url = http://litreactor.com/news/new-book-social-media-site-booklikes-now-open | work = LitReactor | accessdate=12 October 2013|date = 17 May 2013|last = Shultz|first = Christopher}}</ref> Before its public launch in the current format, BookLikes had won an award as the most innovative small business in Greater Poland, on April 17, 2012.<ref name = "BookLikes: Company Info/Timeline"/>{{primary source inline|date=December 2016}}<ref name="Huffington Post: If You Like Books, You'll Like BookLikes (September 9, 2013)">{{cite news | title= If You Like Books, You'll Like BookLikes | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/john-pavley/if-you-like-books-youll-l_b_3893860.html | work = [[Huffington Post]] | accessdate=12 October 2013|date = 9 September 2013|last = Pavley|first = John}}</ref> In July 2013, the company also won the Microsoft BizSpark People's Choice Award, at the Microsoft BizSpark Euro Summit in Berlin.<ref name="Microsoft TechNet/BizSpark Featured Startup on Azure – BookLikes (August 6, 2013)">{{cite web | title= Featured Startup on Azure – BookLikes | url = http://blogs.technet.com/b/bizspark_group_blog/archive/2013/07/04/bringing-volume-to-serendipity-bizspark-grows-under-microsoft-ventures-germany-opens-microsoft-accelerator-to-packed-event.aspx | work = Microsoft TechNet/BizSpark | accessdate=12 October 2013|date = 4 July 2013}}</ref>
As of October 2013, the website's offices are in Poland; however, founder and CEO Dawid Piaskowski said in a June 2013 interview with the [[Los Angeles Times]] that its owners were contemplating a move of its headquarters to the United States, either to New York City or to California, before the end of 2013.<ref name="Los Angeles Times: Can Booklikes be the next Goodreads? (June 11, 2013)">{{cite news | title= Can Booklikes be the next Goodreads? | url = http://articles.latimes.com/2013/jun/11/entertainment/la-et-jc-can-booklikes-be-the-next-goodreads-20130529 | work = Los Angeles Times | accessdate=12 October 2013|date = 11 June 2013|last = Kellogg|first = Carolyn}}</ref> Also as of October 2013, roughly 45% of the site's visitors come from the United States; other countries where the website is growing in popularity include Poland, Belgium, Canada, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, Germany, and Egypt.<ref name="BookLikes Alexa Ranking"/>
== History == A first version of BookLikes was launched in June 2011 as a book recommendation engine and social network; a self-described "Facebook for book lovers with price comparison" similar to [[Goodreads]], substantially relying on its own sophisticated book recommendation engine.<ref name = "BookLikes: Company Info/Timeline"/>{{primary source inline|date=December 2016}}<ref name="Huffington Post: If You Like Books, You'll Like BookLikes (September 9, 2013)"/><ref name="TechCrunch: BookLikes.com Attempts To Out-Suggest Amazon (September 14, 2011)">{{cite web | title= BookLikes.com Attempts To Out-Suggest Amazon | url = https://techcrunch.com/2011/09/14/booklikes-com-attempts-to-out-suggest-amazon/|work = TechCrunch | accessdate=12 October 2013|date = 14 September 2011|last = Biggs|first = John}}</ref> In this version, the site was presented throughout 2011 at major startup and technology fairs such as [[Seedcamp]] (New York), [[TechCrunch Disrupt]] (San Francisco), and the 2011 Vienna Startup Week.
During the first months of 2012, a new CTO was hired (Daniel Szwarc), and a German version of the service was launched. The growth of [[Goodreads]], as well as the loss of part of BookLikes's data on the servers of the company initially entrusted with hosting those data, and the discovery that the recommendation engine on which the service, until then, had chiefly relied, was not reaching the site's users in the intended way. This prompted the founders to fundamentally revisit the site's conception. They then redesigned it in the [[Tumblr]]-like interactive blog format in which it was eventually launched in May 2013, having won an award as the most innovative small company in Greater Poland already in April 2012.<ref name="BookLikes: Company Info/Timeline"/>{{primary source inline|date=December 2016}}<ref name="Huffington Post: If You Like Books, You'll Like BookLikes (September 9, 2013)"/><ref name="Microsoft TechNet/BizSpark Featured Startup on Azure – BookLikes (August 6, 2013)"/>
Within five months of its launch in the redesigned format, the site became one of the top 20,000 websites operative in the United States, the sixth highest-ranked startup in Poland, and one of the top 530-ranked startups worldwide.<ref name = "BookLikes Alexa Ranking"/><ref name="BookLikes StartUpRanking data">{{cite web | title=BookLikes StartUpRanking data | url = http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/booklikes.com | publisher= Alexa | accessdate= 12 October 2013}}</ref> In July 2013, it also won the influential Microsoft BizSpark People's Choice Award, at the Microsoft BizSpark Euro Summit in Berlin.<ref name="Microsoft TechNet/BizSpark Featured Startup on Azure – BookLikes (August 6, 2013)"/> Like [[LibraryThing]], BookLikes was a major beneficiary of (former) [[Goodreads]] users' move towards other book-oriented internet platforms in the wake of [[Goodreads]]'s acquisition by [[Amazon.com]] and a [http://www.goodreads.com/topic/show/1499741-important-note-regarding-reviews September 2013 change of review-related policy], which left a number of Goodreads users dissatisfied.<ref name="The Digital Reader: Looking for a Replacement for Goodreads? Try Booklikes (September 21, 2013)">{{cite web | title= Looking for a Replacement for Goodreads? Try Booklikes | url = http://www.the-digital-reader.com/2013/09/21/looking-replacement-goodreads-try-booklikes | work = The Digital Reader | accessdate=12 October 2013|date = 21 September 2013|last = Hoffelder|first = Nate}}</ref><ref name="BookLikes on Twitter: We are getting a HUGE amount of users registering and using BL! (September 22, 2013)">{{cite web | title= BookLikes|url = http://dx5y3z85enc4t.cloudfront.net/540x540/fit/hostedimages/1380298426/683678.jpg | work = BookLikes/Twitter | accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref><ref name="LibraryThing: Welcome Goodreads refugees!">{{cite web | title=Welcome Goodreads refugees! |url = http://www.librarything.com/topic/152048 | work = LibraryThing | accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref><ref name="Salon.com: How Amazon and Goodreads could lose their best readers (October 24, 2013)">{{cite web | title=How Amazon and Goodreads could lose their best readers | url = http://www.salon.com/2013/10/23/how_amazon_and_goodreads_could_lose_their_best_readers/singleton | work = Salon.com | accessdate=24 October 2013}}</ref><ref name="Washington Post: Is Goodreads’ new policy really censorship? (September 23, 2013)">{{cite news | title=Is Goodreads’ new policy really censorship? |url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/compost/wp/2013/09/23/is-good-reads-new-policy-really-censorship/ | work = Washington Post | accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref><ref name="Salon.com: Goodreads: Where readers and authors battle it out in an online 'Lord of the Flies' (October 10, 2013)">{{cite web | title=Goodreads: Where readers and authors battle it out in an online 'Lord of the Flies' |url = http://www.salon.com/2013/10/09/goodreads_where_readers_and_authors_battle_it_out_in_an_online_lord_of_the_flies/ | work = Salon.com | accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref><ref name="Salon.com: Amazon buys Goodreads: We’re all just data now (March 31, 2013)">{{cite web | title=Amazon buys Goodreads: We’re all just data now | url = http://www.salon.com/2013/03/31/amazon_buys_goodreads_were_all_just_data_now/ | work = Salon.com | accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref><ref name="Forbes: Three Hidden Benefits of The Amazon Acquisition of Goodreads (March 29, 2013)">{{cite news | title=Three Hidden Benefits of The Amazon Acquisition of Goodreads | url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidvinjamuri/2013/03/29/three-hidden-benefits-of-the-amazon-acquisition-of-goodreads/ | work = Forbes | accessdate=12 October 2013 | first=David | last=Vinjamuri}}</ref>
== Features == BookLikes is currently available in three different languages, English, German, and Polish, and plans to add further languages in the future. On the BookLikes website, users can add books to their standard and personal bookshelves, rate and review books, see what their friends are reading, participate in discussion boards and groups on a variety of topics, and get suggestions for future reading choices. Once a user starts following other users, he will see the users' updates and reviews in his or her "Dashboard" feed. BookLikes also adds their own blog updates to a user's feed. The site provides default bookshelves—Read, Currently reading, Planning to read—and the opportunity to create customized shelves to categorize a user's books. Every book that is added by a user can be added to a [[Wish list|wishlist]] or be marked as favorite or private.<ref name="Huffington Post: If You Like Books, You'll Like BookLikes (September 9, 2013)"/>
Similar to [[Tumblr]]'s interface, it lets users access the site on two different levels. On the one hand, a site-wide level, which includes a "Dashboard" feed of items posted by BookLikes and updates from users the user chooses to follow. It also shows the features and services provided directly by BookLikes, such as its recommendation engine, site-related widgets, a presentation of top reviewers, book-related giveaways, "Daily Deals" and other so-called "Goodies", a "friend invite" scheme, discussion groups, and certified author pages for users who are authors themselves.<ref name="BookLikes: Product info">{{cite web | title= Product info | url = http://booklikes.com/press/21/product-info | work = BookLikes | accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref>{{primary source inline|date=December 2016}}<ref name="BookLikes: Press Release, May 14, 2013">{{cite web | title= Press Release | url = http://booklikes.com/press/37/press-release | work = BookLikes | accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref>{{primary source inline|date=December 2016}}<ref name="BookLikes: FAQ">{{cite web | title= FAQ | url = http://booklikes.com/page/18/faq | work = BookLikes | accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref>{{primary source inline|date=December 2016}}<ref name="BookLikes: Community Guidelines">{{cite web | title= Community Guidelines | url = http://blog.booklikes.com/post/198757/booklikes-community-guidelines|work = BookLikes | accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref>{{primary source inline|date=December 2016}} The site also created an official BookLikes group where users can offer feedback and suggestions for new features.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://blog.booklikes.com/post/632730|title = Discussion Rooms - Create Groups and Book Clubs|accessdate = 17 October 2013|date = 17 October 2013|website = BookLikes}}</ref> On a second, parallel level, users create their own blogs which other users can subscribe to and which can be customized based on templates provided by BookLikes. The website allows users to link their own website or blog with BookLikes, which then replaces the blog BookLikes offers its users. Users may also customize their blog's layout with [[HTML]].<ref name="Huffington Post: If You Like Books, You'll Like BookLikes (September 9, 2013)"/><ref name="Microsoft TechNet/BizSpark Featured Startup on Azure – BookLikes (August 6, 2013)"/><ref name="The Digital Reader: Looking for a Replacement for Goodreads? Try Booklikes (September 21, 2013)"/><ref name="BookLikes: Product info"/>{{primary source inline|date=December 2016}}<ref name="BookLikes: Press Release, May 14, 2013"/><ref name="BookLikes: FAQ"/><ref name="BookLikes: Community Guidelines"/>{{primary source inline|date=December 2016}}
Users can write posts and each post can be marked as a review. BookLikes features a rating system of one to five stars, with the option of using half-stars. Users can accompany their review with a rating or rate a work without writing a review. By reblogging posts, users can share reviews or updates of other users or repost their own updates and users can like posts of others.<ref name="Huffington Post: If You Like Books, You'll Like BookLikes (September 9, 2013)"/>
The website facilitates reader interactions with authors through giveaways, authors' blogs, and profile information.<ref name="Huffington Post: If You Like Books, You'll Like BookLikes (September 9, 2013)"/>
Since March 2013, BookLikes also allows its users to link their BookLikes account to [[affiliate marketing]] programs, such as [[Amazon.com]] Associates and [[The Book Depository]] Affiliates in order to generate revenue.<ref name="BookLikes: Press Release, May 14, 2013"/>{{primary source inline|date=December 2016}} The profits of these affiliate programs go entirely to the users.<ref name="Huffington Post: If You Like Books, You'll Like BookLikes (September 9, 2013)"/><ref name="Microsoft TechNet/BizSpark Featured Startup on Azure – BookLikes (August 6, 2013)"/><ref name="The Digital Reader: Looking for a Replacement for Goodreads? Try Booklikes (September 21, 2013)"/><ref name="BookLikes: Affiliate programs">{{cite web | title= Affiliate programs | url = http://booklikes.com/settings/affiliate|work = BookLikes | accessdate=15 October 2013}}</ref>{{primary source inline|date=December 2016}} Book data are sourced through a cooperation with major book sellers in the [[United States]], the [[United Kingdom]], [[Canada]], [[Poland]], [[Germany]], [[France]], [[Austria]], [[Italy]], [[Spain]], the [[Netherlands]], [[Sweden]], and [[China]]; according to the site's press release at the time of its May 2013 launch, the addition of other cooperation partners (also in further countries) is in the works.<ref name="Microsoft TechNet/BizSpark Featured Startup on Azure – BookLikes (August 6, 2013)"/><ref name="BookLikes: Press Release, May 14, 2013" /><ref name="BookLikes: Community Guidelines" />

{{Infobox company | name = C3 Presents | logo = C3presents_logo.png | logo_size = 100px | caption = | type = | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = {{Start date|2007}} | founder = Charles Attal, Charlie Jones and Charlie Walker | defunct = | location_city = [[Austin, Texas]] | location_country = [[United States]] | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = | industry = Concert promotion, event production and artist management | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|C3Presents.com}} | footnotes = | intl = }} '''C3 Presents''' is a concert promotion, event production and artist management company based out of [[Austin, Texas]].[https://www.c3presents.com/ C3 Presents] C3 also produces several iconic multi-day festivals including Austin City Limits Music Festival in Texas,[https://www.aclfestival.com/ ACL Music Festival] Voodoo Music + Arts Experience in New Orleans,[https://www.voodoofestival.com/ Voodoo Festival] and Lollapalooza in Chicago along with its six international editions.[https://www.lollapalooza.com/ Lollapalooza] ==History== C3[https://www.austinchronicle.com/news/2010-10-08/big-dogs-young-rebels-and-aging-giants/ Austin Chronicle Blog] was founded by Charles Attal, Charlie Jones and Charlie Walker in 2007(2)[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/07/arts/music/07lolla.html NY Times] and headquartered in Austin, TX, with offices in Los Angeles, Atlanta, and New Orleans. The company also promotes more than 1,100 concerts annual in arenas, casinos and clubs throughout North America. In the Fall of 2014, Live Nation began talks to purchase a 51% stake in the Austin company’s events production and promotions businesses.[https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/6414053/live-nation-completes-deal-for-c3-presents Live Nation Completes Deal][https://www.austinchronicle.com/daily/music/2015-02-26/c3-presents-and-live-nation-team-up/ C3 and LiveNation Team Up][https://consequenceofsound.net/2014/12/live-nation-acquires-controlling-interest-in-lollapaloozaacl-promoter-c3-presents/ Consequence Of Sound] At the time, C3 was largest independent concert promoter in the world.[https://www.bizjournals.com/austin/blog/at-the-watercooler/2014/12/live-nation-buys-ownership-stake-in-austins Live Nation buys ownership stake] The deal was completed in December of that year. ==Events== Annually, C3 Presents produces the following festivals: • All Things Go Fall Classic[https://www.allthingsgofallclassic.com All Things Go]
• Auckland City Limits Music Festival [https://www.aucklandcitylimits.com Auckland City Limits Music Festival]
• Austin City Limits Music Festival [https://www.aclfestival.com/ ACL Music Festival]
• Austin Food + Wine Festival [https://www.austinfoodandwinefestival.com/ Austin Food + Wine Festival ]
• Chipotle Cultivate Festival [http://eventintelligencegroup.com/chipotle-cultivate-kansas-city-bbq-and-counting-people/ Chipotle Cultivate]
• In Bloom Music Festival (formerly FPSF) [https://www.inbloomfestival.com/ In Bloom Music Festival]
• Innings Music Festival [https://www.inningsfestival.com/ Innings Music Festival]
• Lollapalooza Argentina [https://www.lollapaloozaar.com/ Lollapalooza Argentina]
• Lollapalooza Berlin [https://www.lollapaloozade.com/ Lollapalooza Berlin]
• Lollapalooza Brazil [https://www.lollapaloozabr.com/ Lollapalooza Brazil]
• Lollapalooza Chicago [https://www.lollapalooza.com/ Lollapalooza]
• Lollapalooza Chile [https://www.lollapaloozacl.com/ Lollapalooza Chile]
• Lollapalooza Paris [https://www.lollaparis.com/ Lollapalooza Paris]
• Lollapalooza Stockholm [https://variety.com/2018/music/news/lollapalooza-stockholm-sweden-to-launch-in-2019-1202825166/ Lollapalooza Stockholm]

• NFL Draft [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/29/sports/football/persistent-mayor-gets-his-pick-nfl-draft-comes-to-chicago.html NFL Draft]
• Shaky Beats Music Festival [https://www.shakybeatsfestival.com/ Shaky Beats Music Festival]
• Shaky Knees Music Festival [https://www.shakykneesfestival.com/ Shaky Knees Music Festival]
• Sydney City Limits Music Festival [https://www.sydneycitylimits.com/ Sydney City Limits Music Festival]
• Voodoo Music + Arts Experience [https://www.voodoofestival.com/ Voodoo Festival]
• Obama Election Night Celebration (2008 and 2012) [https://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/touring/1276167/c3-presents-to-provide-services-for-obama-concert-parade C3 Presents To Provide Services]{{cite web|author1=Ray Waddell|title=C3 Presents To Provide Services For Obama Concert, Parade|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/touring/1276167/c3-presents-to-provide-services-for-obama-concert-parade|website=Billboard Biz|publisher=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=25 January 2015|date=16 January 2009}}{{cite web|author1=Jack Goodall|title=BaROCK Obama’s Inauguration|url=http://www.thembj.org/2009/03/barock-obama’s-inauguration/|website=The Music Business Journal|publisher=[[Berklee College of Music]]|accessdate=25 January 2015|date=March 2009}}
• Obama White House Easter Egg Roll [https://www.pollstarpro.com/NewsContent.aspx?cat=&com=1&ArticleID=812013 PollstarPro] C3 also books and promotes over 1,000 shows nationwide, including Austin venues [[Stubb's BBQ]], [[Emo's]] and La Zona Rosa. ===Artist management=== In addition to promotion and production, C3 Presents also has an artist management division operating in New York City, Los Angeles, Nashville, and Austin. C3 Management has a current roster of over 50 musicians {{Cite web |url=http://www.c3presents.com/artistmanagement.aspx# |title=C3 Presents Clients |access-date=2010-12-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101121064721/http://www.c3presents.com/artistmanagement.aspx# |archive-date=2010-11-21 |dead-url=yes |df= }} including The Strokes, Phoenix, Lindsey Buckingham, My Bloody Valentine, The Head And The Heart, The Revivalists, Justice, Sylvan Esso, and Gramatik.[https://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/legal-and-management/5869579/matt-shay-joins-c3s-management-division Matt Shay Joins] The company also maintains its own freestanding radio promotion, film/TV, digital, and creative staffs.[https://www.pollstarpro.com/NewsContent.aspx?cat=&com=1&ArticleID=812013 PollstarPro] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Talent and literary agencies]]
